SubcontrolDescription: Implement real-time system performance monitoring.
Evidence: AWS automatically provides underlying service monitoring for Cognito; customers rely on AWS service health

SubcontrolDescription: Implement security hardening guidelines for all system installations.
Evidence: Security hardening of the Cognito service infrastructure is handled by AWS. Danske Bank teams which utilize this service in their systems design will need to deploy resources via approved Terraform

SubcontrolDescription: Establish alerting mechanisms for system performance degradation.
Evidence: AWS is responsible for the performance and availability of Cognito (monitored internally by AWS)

SubcontrolDescription: Use role-based access control (RBAC) or attribute-based access control (ABAC).
Evidence: Both RBAC and ABAC are supported for Cognito access control. ABAC requires a well-defined tag strategy and IAM policy enforcement. Recommended IAM setup aligns with this requirement.

SubcontrolDescription: Regularly audit and update server configurations.
Evidence: AWS Config or similar tools should be used to monitor Cognito resource configurations for unauthorized changes

SubcontrolDescription: Implement role-based access controls for all business applications.
Evidence: Both RBAC and ABAC are supported for Cognito access control. ABAC requires a well-defined tag strategy and IAM policy enforcement. Recommended IAM setup aligns with this requirement.

SubcontrolDescription: Avoid using deprecated cryptographic algorithms.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito encrypts all customer data at rest (AWS-managed, AES-256). Data is protected in transit with TLS 1.2+. Underlying storage (user directories) is encrypted and replicated by AWS. More info: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html

SubcontrolDescription: Implement strong access controls for shared storage systems.
Evidence: Use IAM resource policies (on Cognito user/identity pools) and ABAC via tags to enforce fine-grained access control

SubcontrolDescription: Require labeling and tagging of classified information.
Evidence: It is recommended that Amazon Cognito resources (user and identity pools) be tagged and utilize IAM attribute-based access control (ABAC) for access scoping and accountability.

SubcontrolDescription: Align risk assessments with regulatory and compliance requirements.
Evidence: All services at Danske Bank are reviewed annually in line with bank policy.

SubcontrolDescription: Implement access restrictions and tracking for sensitive digital assets.
Evidence: Cognito access is controlled through IAM roles and policies defined by the customer. AWS does not grant permissions by default—customers must implement job-role-based access. RBAC (role-based access control) in Cognito is enforced through IAM policies, which must be configured by the customer. We must enable logging and write IAM policies to restrict sensitive operations.

SubcontrolDescription: Require multi-factor authentication (MFA) for cloud service access.
Evidence: MFA is mandatory for all IAM users administering Cognito. (Amazon Cognito user pools also support enabling user MFA via SMS or TOTP.)

SubcontrolDescription: Perform regular penetration testing on critical systems and applications.
Evidence: Applications using Cognito should be included in annual penetration tests. (Note: AWS Cognito service itself cannot be directly attacked under AWS policy.) Penetration Testing services must be conducted annually, and can be requested here: https://home.danskenet.net/sites/securityportal/SitePages/ServiceCatalogue.aspx?area=19&bso=26

SubcontrolDescription: Enforce encryption policies for data at rest and in transit.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito encrypts all customer data at rest (AWS-managed, AES-256). Data is protected in transit with TLS 1.2+. Underlying storage (user directories) is encrypted and replicated by AWS. More info: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html TLS 1.2+ and AES-256 are enforced automatically for Amazon Cognito; encryption cannot be disabled: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html Encryption at rest and in transit are automatically enforced by AWS for Cognito; customers cannot disable them. AWS enforces modern cryptographic standards (e.g., TLS 1.2+ with strong ciphers) for Amazon Cognito communications.

SubcontrolDescription: Conduct security assessments before deploying new systems.
Evidence: Vulnerability scanning of AWS-managed services (including Cognito) is handled by AWS.

SubcontrolDescription: Implement role-based access controls (RBAC) for managing virtual resources.
Evidence: Cognito access is controlled through IAM roles and policies defined by the customer. AWS does not grant permissions by default—customers must implement job-role-based access. RBAC (role-based access control) in Cognito is enforced through IAM policies, which must be configured by the customer. We must enable logging and write IAM policies to restrict sensitive operations.

SubcontrolDescription: Use automated static analysis tools for detecting security issues in code.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito is a managed service; CI/CD code scanning applies to customer applications, not the Cognito service. Amazon Cognito is a managed service.

SubcontrolDescription: Apply standardized security configurations to all servers.
Evidence: Using IaC (Terraform) is mandatory unless alternative is authorized

SubcontrolDescription: Development and production environments should be strictly segregated.
Evidence: Use separate Cognito user/identity pools for dev, test, and prod, and tag resources to segregate environments. LINK TO ENVIRONMENT SEGREGATION: https://confluence.danskenet.net/spaces/MC/pages/829270889/AWS+Organizations+OU+Structure

SubcontrolDescription: Retain logs for an appropriate period for forensic investigations.
Evidence: CloudTrail logs for Cognito (management API calls) must be delivered to S3/SecOps with a retention policy

SubcontrolDescription: Access to development systems should be restricted based on job roles.
Evidence: Cognito access is controlled through IAM roles and policies defined by the customer. AWS does not grant permissions by default—customers must implement job-role-based access. RBAC (role-based access control) in Cognito is enforced through IAM policies, which must be configured by the customer. We must enable logging and write IAM policies to restrict sensitive operations.

SubcontrolDescription: Implement access logging and monitoring.
Evidence: Monitor Cognito via CloudTrail (for API calls) and CloudWatch (for user activity). Logs and events should be forwarded to SIEM (QRadar). More info: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/monitoring.html#:~:text=,and%20when%20it%20was%20made

SubcontrolDescription: Implement automated backup processes for critical data.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito is multi-AZ by default, but AWS provides a User Profiles Export solution to back up user data. Consider implementing this reference architecture to export key user pool data. More Info: https://aws.amazon.com/solutions/guidance/user-profiles-export-with-amazon-cognito/#:~:text=This%20Guidance%20demonstrates%20how%20to,over%20Amazon%20Cognito%20user%20data

SubcontrolDescription: Regularly evaluate security controls for effectiveness and compliance.
Evidence: All services at Danske Bank are reviewed annually in line with bank policy.

SubcontrolDescription: Apply access controls based on classification levels.
Evidence: IAM tagging and ABAC allow classification-based controls (e.g., env:prod, team:alpha).

SubcontrolDescription: Conduct regular vulnerability scans and assessments of systems and applications.
Evidence: AWS conducts vulnerability scanning on its managed Cognito infrastructure

SubcontrolDescription: Implement deny-by-default rules and allow only necessary traffic.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito is a regional service without VPC endpoints or PrivateLink. Access is controlled via IAM, not network ACLs.

SubcontrolDescription: Implement centralized logging and monitoring solutions.
Evidence: All logs related to CodeDeploy (CloudTrail, CloudWatch Events) must be forwarded to the centralized SIEM (QRadar) for correlation and alerting.

SubcontrolDescription: Conduct regular Business Impact Analyses (BIA) to assess risk exposure.
Evidence: All systems using Cognito must have a completed business impact assessment. All systems deployed within Danske Bank must have a completed business impact assessment. Step-by-step: BC processes explained: https://confluence.danskenet.net/pages/releaseview.action?pageId=542943247#Stepbystep:BCprocessesexplained-DevelopingBCdocuments

SubcontrolDescription: Establish cloud security governance aligned with internal risk management frameworks.
Evidence: All bank products in Cloud must be managed by Prisma Cloud.

SubcontrolDescription: Ensure secure decommissioning of obsolete systems.
Evidence: In the event that a system will decommission Cognito, all persistent data and access must be removed/sanitized.

SubcontrolDescription: Regularly rotate cryptographic keys and enforce strong key management policies.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito uses AWS-managed encryption keys. AWS rotates these keys automatically and customers cannot directly manage or rotate them.

SubcontrolDescription: Encrypt sensitive documents stored digitally.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito encrypts all customer data at rest (AWS-managed, AES-256). Data is protected in transit with TLS 1.2+. Underlying storage (user directories) is encrypted and replicated by AWS. More info: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html TLS 1.2+ and AES-256 are enforced automatically for Amazon Cognito; encryption cannot be disabled: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html Encryption at rest and in transit are automatically enforced by AWS for Cognito; customers cannot disable them. AWS enforces modern cryptographic standards (e.g., TLS 1.2+ with strong ciphers) for Amazon Cognito communications.

SubcontrolDescription: Automated security scanning should be integrated into CI/CD pipelines.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito is a managed service; CI/CD code scanning applies to customer applications, not the Cognito service. Amazon Cognito is a managed service.

SubcontrolDescription: Security requirements should be defined and documented for all new system developments.
Evidence: Teams, that are utilizing this service, must take their solution through the Assessment Process Engine

SubcontrolDescription: Implement cloud security monitoring and access controls.
Evidence: Use IAM roles and policies to enforce least-privilege access for Cognito management. All administrative API calls are logged to AWS CloudTrail

SubcontrolDescription: Implement strong encryption standards for data at rest and in transit.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito encrypts all customer data at rest (AWS-managed, AES-256). Data is protected in transit with TLS 1.2+. Underlying storage (user directories) is encrypted and replicated by AWS. More info: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html TLS 1.2+ and AES-256 are enforced automatically for Amazon Cognito; encryption cannot be disabled: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html Encryption at rest and in transit are automatically enforced by AWS for Cognito; customers cannot disable them. AWS enforces modern cryptographic standards (e.g., TLS 1.2+ with strong ciphers) for Amazon Cognito communications.

SubcontrolDescription: Store encryption keys securely using hardware security modules (HSMs).
Evidence: AWS Key Management Service (used by Cognito) is backed by FIPS 140-2 validated HSMs.

SubcontrolDescription: Conduct regular BCP tests, including tabletop exercises and simulations.
Evidence: Disaster recovery of AWS services (including Amazon Cognito) is handled by AWS per our service agreement.

SubcontrolDescription: Systems should be patched and updated before deployment.
Evidence: AWS manages patching of the Cognito service infrastructure

SubcontrolDescription: Require peer review of all critical code for security vulnerabilities.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito is an AWS-managed service; code review applies to Danske Bank’s own development processes, not to Cognito itself

SubcontrolDescription: Enforce encryption for data stored in cloud services.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito automatically encrypts all data at rest using AWS-managed keys (AES-256). Data in transit requires TLS 1.2+. Customer-managed keys are not supported by Cognito. More info: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/data-protection.html

SubcontrolDescription: Standardized security hardening guidelines should be followed for system builds.
Evidence: Enforce hardened baseline configurations via infrastructure-as-code (e.g. Terraform) and policy tools

SubcontrolDescription: Implement redundant systems for critical applications.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito is designed for high availability. It is distributed across multiple Availability Zones in each region. More info: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cognito/latest/developerguide/what-is-amazon-cognito.html#:~:text=Amazon%20Cognito%20is%20available%20in,redundancy%2C%20while%20also%20minimizing%20latency

SubcontrolDescription: Encrypt backup data and store copies in a secure location.
Evidence: Any backups of Cognito data (e.g. exports to Amazon S3) must be encrypted at rest (use S3 encryption policies or bucket encryption)

SubcontrolDescription: Use geographically distributed data centers for disaster recovery.
Evidence: Amazon Cognito is regional and has no built-in cross-region replication. AWS recommends using multi-region export/import of user pools for DR. More info: https://aws.amazon.com/solutions/guidance/user-profiles-export-with-amazon-cognito/#:~:text=This%20Guidance%20demonstrates%20how%20to,over%20Amazon%20Cognito%20user%20data

SubcontrolDescription: Require security impact assessments before implementing system changes.
Evidence: AWS ensures Cognito service security (impact assessments) as part of its operational processes

SubcontrolDescription: Utilize automated security scanning tools to identify vulnerabilities.
Evidence: AWS conducts vulnerability scanning on its managed Cognito infrastructure

SubcontrolDescription: Implement documented configuration standards for routers, firewalls, and switches.
Evidence: This is an AWS-managed service; network infrastructure configuration is handled by AWS under the shared responsibility model

SubcontrolDescription: Perform penetration testing on all critical systems before deployment.
Evidence: Applications using Cognito should be included in annual penetration tests. (Note: AWS Cognito service itself cannot be directly attacked under AWS policy.) Penetration Testing services must be conducted annually, and can be requested here: https://home.danskenet.net/sites/securityportal/SitePages/ServiceCatalogue.aspx?area=19&bso=26
